facts: The first regular television broadcasts began in the 1930s, but TV became common in many homes after World War II.
Early televisions were mostly black-and-white, and color TV became widely popular in the 1960s and 1970s.
A TV image is made from tiny dots of light called pixels, and more pixels usually means a sharper picture.
Television shows are often filmed with multiple cameras so editors can quickly switch angles during conversations and action scenes.
A “pilot” episode is a test version of a show that helps a network decide whether to order a full season.
Live broadcasts use studios, control rooms, and timed cues so cameras, sound, and graphics happen at the right moment.
Streaming services deliver TV through the internet, which lets viewers watch episodes on demand instead of at a scheduled time.
